ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Miscellaneous comments on study, interview, methodology relevant to this form data
General acceptability: this approach would be appropriate for a variety of therapists
Notes: 1 = strongly disagree; 2 = moderately disagree; 3 = slightly disagree; 4 = slightly agree; 5 = moderately agree; 6 = strongly agree

ElementDescription: Effectiveness: the training would be beneficial for the therapists
Notes: 1 = strongly disagree; 2 = moderately disagree; 3 = slightly disagree; 4 = slightly agree; 5 = moderately agree; 6 = strongly agree

ElementDescription: Negative side effects: the training will result in disruption or harm to clients
Notes: 1 = strongly disagree; 2 = moderately disagree; 3 = slightly disagree; 4 = slightly agree; 5 = moderately agree; 6 = strongly agree

ElementDescription: Appropriateness: most therapists would not accept that the training provided an appropriate approach to client care
Notes: 1 = strongly disagree; 2 = moderately disagree; 3 = slightly disagree; 4 = slightly agree; 5 = moderately agree; 6 = strongly agree

ElementDescription: Consistency: the training was consistent with common sense and good practice in helping therapists to work effectively
Notes: 1 = strongly disagree; 2 = moderately disagree; 3 = slightly disagree; 4 = slightly agree; 5 = moderately agree; 6 = strongly agree

ElementDescription: Social Validity: in an overall, general sense, most therpaists would approve of this method (e.g. would recommend it to others)
Notes: 1 = strongly disagree; 2 = moderately disagree; 3 = slightly disagree; 4 = slightly agree; 5 = moderately agree; 6 = strongly agree

ElementDescription: Did the workshop improve your understanding?
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: Did the workshop help you develop work-related skills?
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: Has the workshop made you more confident?
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: Do you expect to make use of what you learnt in the workshop in your workplace?
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: How competent were the workshop leaders?
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: In an overall, general sense, how satisfied are you with the workshop?
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: Did the workshop cover the topics it set out to cover?
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: Did the workshop leaders relate to the group effectively? (e.g., made you feel comfortable and understood)
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: Were the leaders motivating? (e.g., energetic, attentive, and creative)
Notes: 0 = Not at all; 1 = A little; 2 = Quite a lot; 3 = A great deal

ElementDescription: What was the most helpful part of the workshop for you personally?
What change, if any, would you recommend? (e.g., to the content of teaching)
Please make any other comments that you would like to offer.
